Yes Gary(es), interesting indeed. To go on, only 4th, 6th, 10th, 12th etc. powers of odd prime numbers will have 4, 6, 10, 12 etc. trapezoidal representations.

If the number of trapezoidal representations is p-1, where p is a prime number, then only powers (p-1) of any prime number will qualify. The beauty of Ricardo's formula makes it almost obvious. However, one almost misses it because you first add one then subtract one to obtain the count of representations.
I guess I should have written "...prime numbers greater than 2..." rather than "...odd prime numbers...", to exclude 1.
Also power-of-two multiples of these numbers, so 162 (2 * 3^4) or 648  (2^3 * 3^4) would also have only four trapezoidal representations, since the powers of two drop out.

Here is a suggestion for Governor Cuomo:
Unless we are not playing with a full deck, the disclosure made in connection with an application for a gun permit that the applicant drinks alcohol excessivley would undoubtedly cause a denial of the application. From this it must follow that, upon the lawful arrest of the holder of a gun permit for driving while intoxicated, the evidence supporting the arrest is a sufficient predicate for the temporary suspension of the permit.

A statute providing for such a suspension, whether compelled or left to the discretion of the court, diminishes the risk of death or injury by defendant’s use of his gun, a defendant who ordinarily is unknown to the court and whose conduct suggests that the defendant may be troubled and may have an impaired judgment. Further, delay will infuse itself into the action. The consequences of a finding of guilt are substantial and rare is the defendant who yearns for a speedy disposition. His attorney will inquire into every factual and legal test available to the defendant. In short, unless there is a suspension of the gun permit and a handing over of the gun to the police, the risks attending defendant’s continued possession of his gun are increasedby the inevitable delay.

Respectfully, the Governor should consider a bill providing for the suspension of a gun permit during the pendency of an action for driving while intoxicated. It may save lives.

You reduce the resistance to Sen. Hagel's nomination largely to a willingness to go to war, when that is not the sum of reasons his detractors cite. If that were the only issue and if he truly believes that force is a legitimate option when not employed thoughtlessly, then there would be few who resist his nomination.

But his other, short-shrifted views on Israel and on Iran, suggest a false sense of Realpolitik (false because it's based on a two-dimensional appreciation of our real interests) that is unlikely to define then defend our true interests in the region. One has the sense that he will spend his time merely avoiding confrontation so we can kick cans down the road and the military does not become an impediment to Mr. Obama's manifest desire to Europeanize both our economy and culture on the back of our ability to defend ourselves. That works for the Euros, who can depend on us to defend them while they spend what they would otherwise spend on defense on their entitlement frameworks and social safety nets; but who subsidizes US in the face of a rising China, a Russia seeking to regain global influence and a reawakening and militaristic Islam?

Finally, Sen. Hagel may have been chosen precisely because his views are so similar to the president's: that's Mr. Obama's right, but it could be dangerous. Hagel is likely to make the same mistakes globally as the president, and not serve that president as a set of eyes with different filters that see other colors.
